title: 109_hr1515
content:
The Act is titled the "Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve Boundary Adjustment Act of 2006". It involves adjusting the boundaries of the Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve. The National Parks and Recreation Act of 1978 is amended to adjust the boundaries of the Barataria Marsh Unit in the Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve. The land acquisition section is also amended to allow the Secretary to acquire additional land for the Barataria Preserve Unit. The Secretary is authorized to acquire land, water, and interests within the Barataria Preserve Unit by donation, purchase, transfer from other Federal agencies, or exchange. Federal land in specific areas must be transferred to the National Park Service without consideration. The Secretary may acquire private interests in the Barataria Preserve Unit with owner consent. Federal land in specific areas must be transferred to the National Park Service without consideration. The Secretary can acquire private interests in the Barataria Preserve Unit with owner consent. Federal land in specific areas must be transferred to the National Park Service without consideration. The legislation includes provisions for the acquisition of state land, water, and interests in land and water, as well as the protection of fresh water drainage patterns, vegetative cover, ecological and biological systems, and water and air quality in the Barataria Preserve Unit. The National Parks and Recreation Act of 1978 is amended to allow the Secretary to manage land, water, and interests in the Barataria Marsh Unit. The legislation also updates administration procedures for the National Parks and Recreation Act. SEC. 3. REFERENCES IN LAW.

Any reference in a law to the Barataria Marsh Unit is now considered a reference to the Barataria Preserve Unit, and any reference to the Jean Lafitte National Historical Park is now considered a reference to the Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve. Amendments have been made to the National Parks and Recreation Act of 1978 to reflect these changes. The House of Representatives passed the document on September 25, 2006, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
